column2: Stevo, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Raptiva was working well and then was withdrawn from the market.  My dermatologist never told me to gradually wean myself off the Raptiva - she just said to use my remaining doses as usual.  About 2 weeks after abruptly stopping the Raptiva, I experienced a massive flare-up of psoriasis, from head to toe (covering at least 75% of my body).  Now I'm taking Methotrexate and applying topical steroids, and have started taking Humira, but after a month there's only been about a 20% improvement.  It may take months before I'm back to where I was before stopping Raptiva.  MAKE SURE YOUR DOCTOR HAS YOU  GRADUALLY STOPPING THE RAPTIVA (if you're still using it).  This is the worst experience of my life.

column2: Mack184, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have tried every treatment that has been available for psoriasis. Raptiva has been a miracle drug for me it cleared me. I have not had any side effects. I am now trying Humira about a month into. I did get a reaction to stopping the Raptiva.

column2: mitchell, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: My husband had had psoriasis for over 30 years.  He passed away May 07 after being on Raptiva for 18 mths.  This was the only medication he was on.  I am convinced his symptoms were masked by the medication,  DO NOT take this drug.  It should have been recalled 3 yrs ago.  I have filed 3 complaints to the FDA.  His doctor continued to dismiss his symptoms. He had a BSI of 80% and should have been hospitalized but was not.  His condition worsened after taking the med and told his doctor of his concern.  He also was not told his condition would worsen when he stopped taking the medication.  DO your own research - do not rely on your physican for all the answers. If you are not getting better find another doctor dont wait. . . .

Psoriasis Drug Raptiva Pulled From U.S. Market04.07.09, 08:00 PM EDTDrug manufacturer acts after link found to rare brain infectionWEDNESDAY, April 8 (HealthDay News) -- The troubled psoriasis drug Raptiva is being withdrawn from the U.S. market, California-based drug maker Genentech ( DNA - news - people ) announced Wednesday.The move comes almost two months after U.S. health officials issued a public health advisory on the drug after confirming a link to a rare, sometimes fatal brain infection.In a prepared release, Genentech said Wednesday, "Effective immediately, physicians should not issue prescriptions for Raptiva for any new patients and should promptly contact patients currently receiving Raptiva to assess the most appropriate treatment alternatives. Raptiva will no longer be available after June 8, 2009."Genentech estimated that approximately 2,000 patients in the United States may currently be using Raptiva (efalizumab) for chronic plaque psoriasis. Since it was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 2003, approximately 46,000 patients worldwide have been treated with Raptiva, the company said."Our decision to remove Raptiva from the market reflects Genentech's commitment to patient safety," said Dr. Hal Barron, Genentech's senior vice president, development and chief medical officer. "Although we believe that many psoriasis patients are benefiting from Raptiva, the balance between benefit and risk in the psoriasis population for which Raptiva was approved has significantly changed."In February, an FDA advisory noted there had been three deaths of people taking the drug. Two involved people with confirmed cases of a rare brain infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). The third death was a person believed to have contracted the brain infection, according to the advisory.http://www.fda.gov/cder/drug/advisor y/efalizumab.htm

column2: Long Term Raptiva User, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was a part of the clinical trials for this drug so I have been taking it since 2000.  It has been a life saver for me.  Without this drug I am covered 90% of my body with it I am totally clear.  I am not sure of the side effects for other people but I have none.  Even if I did have side effects they would be minor compared to the debilitating effects of my psoriasis.  I am SOOO grateful.  If you cannot afford the medication contact Genentech, the manufacturer, ask for their Access To Care foundation.  You can get the medication at no cost or little cost based on your income.  Without them I would not be able to afford it. If you are thinking about stopping the medication, I would tell you to ask your physician.  I tried to discontinue use and had a psoriasis flare that I needed to be in the hospital for.  It was so awful.  I am resigned to giving myself a shot once a week for the rest of my life and I am more than ok with that.  My life is better today because I have Raptiva.  If there are serious long term effects that will remain to be seen for me.  I will have to trade that for the quality of my life that I am having now because of the wonderful effects I have while I am on it.
